awd_titl_txt: High Surface Area Reverse Electrowetting Mechanoelectrical Transduction
awd_abstract_narration:
Self-powered sensors capable of zero-maintenance monitoring and data collection over days to weeks are currently not available for many applications that do not have regular access to solar energy or wireless power transmission. The goal of this research project is to use the high surface area advantage of a liquid-based energy harvesting concept called reverse electrowetting to harvest energy from low-frequency movement and to develop a self-powered motion sensor to detect various movements such as walking and running. A miniaturized integrated circuit (IC) chip will also be developed that will make the energy harvester highly suitable for other industrial and biomedical applications. This technology will make it possible to develop self-powered devices capable of long-term motion sensing that can be useful for monitoring post-operative elderly patients who are recovering from procedures such as joint replacement surgery. The self-powered motion sensor will rely on the harvested kinetic motion as its external energy source and will be capable of long-term operation. Such a wireless sensor has not previously been demonstrated for low-frequency kinetic energy harvesting. Also, as a part of this project, energy harvesting, and circuit design experiences will be added to the University of North Texas (UNT) College of Engineering summer camp for the K-12 youth as well as providing sponsorship for an undergraduate senior design team.
High surface area reverse electrowetting depends on reversible electrolyte movement within a porous electrode with applied pressure or an electric field. Key limiting parameters that have not been previously verified experimentally include electrode pore size, electrolyte conductivity, dielectric type or thickness, surface finish, and the pressure and voltage magnitude or frequency. These parameters will be modeled, optimized, and experimentally validated to achieve the maximum available energy or power for a cm-sized transducer. The hypothesis is: reverse electrowetting is capable of producing 1 mW/cm2 at <10 Hz oscillation frequency through the use of high surface area materials and parameter optimization. These design parameters will be used in the selection and integration of highly porous electrode materials (e.g. sintered metal and buckypaper) with electrolyte, electret, and housing components for maximum low-frequency energy harvesting in a ~5 cm3 package. An integrated circuit (IC) will be developed to convert the harvested energy into a usable constant DC power supply. The system will be integrated with a low-power wireless data transmission circuitry and miniaturized antenna on a flexible PDMS substrate for developing a self-powered, conformable motion sensor. This wearable sensor will be unique as it will be self-powered and low-cost and will demonstrate high surface area reverse electrowetting's ability to harvest enough energy from low-frequency motion to entirely self-power a wearable motion sensor. Specific contributions from this research include: fundamental understanding of high surface area reverse electrowetting, demonstration of reverse electrowetting in a flexible system, highly efficient rectifier and DC-DC converter topologies that can start with as low as 30 mV input voltages, and an integrated self-powered motion sensor with wireless data transmission capability.

por.por_cntn:
This project focuses on developing energy harvesting systems using a technique called reverse electrowetting-on-dielectric (REWOD). REWOD generates electricity by manipulating liquids on flexible, high-surface-area electrodes through mechanical movements such as bending or pressure. The goal is to create self-powered, flexible motion sensors for wearable devices, offering a sustainable energy source without external batteries. This would significantly enhance wearable health sensors by reducing the need for frequent charging and replacement.

The project has made significant progress in simulating REWOD to optimize energy harvesting. Researchers developed a sophisticated analytical model using MATLAB, SolidWorks, and ANSYS to predict how flexible REWOD samples would perform during mechanical stress, such as bending. This model helped determine the best pore geometry and electrode materials to maximize energy generation. Electrical and multiphysics-based modeling explored various electrode designs, such as structured rough surfaces, which showed great potential in increasing energy output without needing external power sources. Modulating small liquid droplets on flexible electrodes was found to generate AC current, a key step in powering wearable devices. In terms of fabrication, several versions of flexible REWOD energy harvesters were created using materials like manganese oxide (MnO2), hafnium oxide (HfO2), and aluminum oxide (Al2O3) deposited on thin flexible substrates, such as polyimide. High-surface-area materials, including aluminum foam and carbon felt, were tested to enhance energy harvesting. The experiments revealed that MnO2-coated devices produced up to 2 V of peak-to-peak AC voltage during bending tests, marking a significant improvement for wearable energy solutions.

The project also explored low-cost methods for scaling up REWOD devices. One approach involved using off-the-shelf materials, like aluminized polyester film, to create flexible, low-cost REWOD devices that scaled easily for large applications. A breakthrough came with the integration of the REWOD energy harvester with wireless data transmission circuitry. The team developed a custom integrated circuit (IC) with an antenna, microprocessor, and charge amplifier, allowing the REWOD harvester to wirelessly transmit motion data. This IC was printed on flexible substrates and successfully tested for durability during activities like walking, demonstrating the feasibility of a fully self-powered wearable motion sensor.

The broader impacts of this research are substantial. By reducing reliance on batteries, REWOD-powered devices offer a sustainable solution, reducing electronic waste and improving device longevity. This technology could be particularly valuable for wearable health sensors that provide long-term monitoring, such as for patients recovering from surgery. The project also provided valuable hands-on training for students at various academic levels, offering experience in advanced simulation, fabrication, and energy harvesting technologies. The rigorous modeling, innovative fabrication techniques, and successful testing make this project a promising step toward commercializing self-powered wearable sensors. The knowledge gained from this work will benefit researchers developing flexible, low-power energy harvesting systems, contributing to sustainable and scalable solutions for various applications.
